com.facebook.litho.sections

Class Section

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.facebook.litho.sections.SectionLifecycle
      • com.facebook.litho.sections.Section
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Equivalence<Section>, EventDispatcher, EventTriggerTarget, HasEventDispatcher, HasEventTrigger, Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DataDiffSection, HideableDataDiffSection, SectionsTestHelper, SingleComponentSection, TestSectionCreator.TestSection, ViewPagerHelperSection

    public abstract class Section
extends SectionLifecycle
implements Cloneable, HasEventDispatcher, HasEventTrigger, Equivalence<Section>
    Represents a unique instance of a Section that is driven by its matching SectionLifecycle. To create new Section instances, use the create() method in the generated SectionLifecycle subclass which returns a Section.Builder that allows you to set values for individual props. Section instances are immutable after creation.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  Section.Builder<T extends Section.Builder<T>>
      A builder to build a Section with a SectionLifecycle L.

      • getKey

        protected String getKey()
        Returns:
        a key for this Section that is local between its siblings. A parent is responsible to set different localScopes to children with the same SectionLifecycle.

      • setKey

        public void setKey(String key)
        Sets the key for this Section. This is only used for testing as the key will be set from the Section.Builder

      • makeShallowCopy

        public Section makeShallowCopy(boolean deepCopy)
        Returns:
        a clone of this Section. if deepCopy is false the clone won't contain any children or count as it will be returned in a pre - ChangeSet generation state.

      • isEquivalentTo

        public boolean isEquivalentTo(Section other)
        Compares this section to a different one to check if they are the same

        This is used to be able to skip rendering a section again. We avoid using the Object.equals(Object) so we can optimize the code better over time since we don't have to adhere to the contract required for a equals method.

        Specified by:
        isEquivalentTo in interface Equivalence<Section>
        Parameters:
        other - the component to compare to
        Returns:
        true if the components are of the same type and have the same props
